name: impulsion
content:
Add to word list
Add to word list
a strong wish to do something: He accused journalists of an impulsion towards sensationalism. The manager felt a long-term impulsion to maintain a united team.
the reason for doing something, or the force pushing something to happen: Progress has already been made in all these areas, in particular under the impulsion of the Europe agreements. Under the influence of certain impulsions, the leadership might move in the correct direction. Synonym
impulseRelated word
impel
More examplesFewer examplesThey recognized the need for more political impulsion behind the project.This work provided much of the early impulsion to the present international project.
